unnormalised: The sun beat down on Govind's back as he surveyed his 2-acre plot in Ahmednagar, Maharashtra. It was a far cry from the manicured fields of his neighbour, Mr. Patil, who relied heavily on chemical fertilizers and pesticides. Govind, however, was a staunch believer in organic farming, a path he'd embraced after attending a workshop conducted by the Krishi Vigyan Kendra in Rahuri back in 2018.
normalised: The sun beat down on Govind's back as he surveyed his two acre plot in Ahmednagar, Maharashtra. It was a far cry from the manicured fields of his neighbour, Mister Patil, who relied heavily on chemical fertilizers and pesticides. Govind, however, was a staunch believer in organic farming, a path he'd embraced after attending a workshop conducted by the Krishi Vigyan Kendra in Rahuri back in two thousand and eighteen.

unnormalised: He remembers his grandfather, Dadasaheb, tilling the same land using traditional methods, long before the Green Revolution swept across India. Dadasaheb always said, "The land is our mother, Govind. We must nourish her, not poison her." Those words resonated deeply with Govind, especially after he saw the detrimental effects of chemical farming on the soil and the health of the villagers.

unnormalised: Initially, the transition was tough. Yields were lower, and pests seemed more persistent. Mr. Patil, with his lush green fields, would often scoff, "Organic farming is for dreamers, Govind. You’ll never make a decent living!" But Govind persevered. He learned to make jeevamrutham, a concoction of cow dung, cow urine, jaggery, and flour, a powerful organic fertilizer. He also introduced companion planting, intercropping marigolds to deter nematodes, a common pest in his tomato crop. He used neem oil, a natural insecticide readily available in any Indian household, to combat aphids.

He used neem oil, a natural insecticide readily available in any Indian household, to combat aphids.

unnormalised: Slowly, things started to improve. The soil, once hard and lifeless, regained its texture and fertility. Earthworms, once scarce, thrived in the organic-rich soil. His vegetables, though not as visually perfect as Mr. Patil's, tasted sweeter and were much healthier. He started selling his produce at the weekly bazaar in Shirdi, where people were increasingly aware of the benefits of organic food. He even managed to secure a contract to supply organic vegetables to a local restaurant.

unnormalised: Today, Govind's farm is a testament to the power of sustainable agriculture. He proudly points to his healthy tomato plants, vibrant spinach patches, and flourishing mango trees. Dr. Sharma from the agricultural university recently visited his farm and was impressed by the biodiversity and soil health. He even suggested Govind’s farm be used as a model for other farmers in the region.

unnormalised: His earnings have increased by about 20% compared to when he used chemical fertilizers, and more importantly, he feels a sense of pride and connection to the land. He even plans to expand his organic farm by another 1000 sq ft next year. He earns approximately Rs. 20,000 per month from his current yields. He hopes his success story will inspire other farmers to embrace organic farming and build a healthier and more sustainable future for India. The journey is long and challenging, but as Dadasaheb always said, "Patience and hard work will always bear fruit." He even dreams of opening a small organic farm stay for tourists visiting Shirdi, showcasing the beauty and benefits of natural farming practices to a wider audience.
